comments.body: We have the functionality of setting up the yarn environment for tests twice now. Here and way further up. We should factor that out, probably in a followup PR.

Well yes, we have two occasions to write json:
(1)
```haskell
        BSL.writeFile "package.json" $ encode (
          object
            [ "private" .= True
            , "devDependencies" .= pkgDevDependencies configConsts
            , "workspaces" .= pkgs
            , "name" .= ("daml2ts" :: T.Text)
            , "version" .= ("0.0.0" :: T.Text)
            ])
```
(2)
```haskell
    writePackageJson :: IO ()
    writePackageJson = BSL.writeFile "package.json" $ encode packageJson
      where
        packageJson = object
          [ "private" .= True
          , "workspaces" .= (["daml2ts"] :: [T.Text])
          , "resolutions" .= HMS.fromList ([("@daml/types", "file:daml-types")] :: [(T.Text, T.Text)])
          ]
```
Although similar, they do have very different contents. Do you still feel this deserves refactoring?
Oh wait! I think you mean we do something similar in the DAML assistant too. Yes, we should definitely factor this out then. I'll put it on the stack with the 2 notes below.

comments.body: I have a suspicion that this only works because we write too much in the `package.json` file for every package. I'm fine with keeping it in there for now and remove it in a followup PR.

I hope your suspicions are unfounded.
```haskell

    packageJson :: Value
    packageJson = object
      [ "name" .= ("daml2ts" :: T.Text)
      , "version" .= version
      , "dependencies" .= pkgDependencies config
      , "devDependencies" .= pkgDevDependencies config
      ]
```
where,
```haskell
configConsts :: T.Text -> ConfigConsts
configConsts sdkVersion = ConfigConsts
  { pkgDependencies = HMS.fromList
      [ (NpmPackageName "@mojotech/json-type-validation", NpmPackageVersion "^3.1.0")
      , (NpmPackageName "@daml/types", NpmPackageVersion sdkVersion)
      ]
  , pkgDevDependencies = HMS.fromList
      [ (NpmPackageName "typescript", NpmPackageVersion "~3.7.3")
      ]
  , pkgScripts = HMS.fromList
      [ (ScriptName "build", Script "tsc")
      , (ScriptName "lint", Script "eslint --ext .ts --max-warnings 0 src/")
      ]
  }
```
Let me know!
Related : I do observe that the `pkgDependencies` are not required for the lint test (in `Daml2ts.hs`). Removing those in this PR.
Does that mean we can delete `pkgScripts`? Let's do that then! ðŸ”¥
Done.

comments.body: Wouldn't it make more sense to update the tests to reflect the new package ids?

No, this test is verifying the error message you get if you have two packages with different names but the same package id. `daml build` wonâ€™t produce such packages anymore with DAML-LF 1.8 since the package name ends up in the metadata  so the package id is actually different. We could manually patch the `MANIFEST.MF` but that doesnâ€™t really solve anything since `daml2ts` should switch to using the package metadata anyway.
I see. That makes sense. Thanks for the explanation.

comments.body: That should be the current SDK version too.
Again, well spotted.
Actually, we might need `0.0.0-SNAPSHOT` here in order to use `@daml/types` from `HEAD`.  The `build-and-list` test should demonstrate how to depend on these.
What do we need this one for?
We don't. Removing.
Actually, turns out we do. Need to write one for the `yarn install` step to work but otherwise don't if we `cd x&& yarn build`.
It turns out we really, really do in order to make our scheme of `yarn install` run once work.

Is there a way to depend on the "global" `node_modules` directory we maintain with bazel? @aherrmann do you know the answer?
If there is, we might get away without using workspaces. If we have to use workspaces, I'd prefer to call `yarn build` and `yarn lint` from the directory containing the generated code rather than calling the `yarn workspaces run ...` versions, which also run over the `@dummy/dummy` package.

@hurryabit You can depend on `"@language_support_ts_deps//:node_modules"` to put them into the sandbox. I'm not sure if there is a way to point yarn to another `node_modules` folder, if not you could create a symlink to put it in the right place.

Alternatively, you could turn the `yarn lint` call into it's own `eslint_test` target. However, that would require some larger refactoring of this PR.
